title: Week 5 Data Import
text:
Week 5 Assignment
###“Write your blog post, and submit the link to this assignment on blackboard. Blog post ideas will be discussed in class, and this assignment will be updated for clarity.
###Ways to view your dATA

#data() , allows you to view all the data sets
#view(cars) , allows you to view specific data sets
#print(cars) , it prints the data to the console
#glimpse(cars) , gives you a small preview of the first 10-20 data points
#head(cars) , gives you a table format of the first 10-20 data points
#summary(cars), gives basic info min, max, mean, median, 1st ,and 3rd interquartile range

###Summarytools

#library(summarytools)
# Error in loading"


Importing data

library(rio)

demo_tsv <- import(file = "data/demo.tsv") # Tab seperate factor
demo_csv  <- import("data/demo.csv")  # comma-separated values
demo_xls  <- import("data/demo.xlsx") # Excel format
demo_sav  <- import("data/demo.sav")  # SPSS format

glimpse(demo_tsv)

Rows: 6
Columns: 6
$ character <chr> "A", "B", "C", "D", "E", "F"
$ factor    <chr> "high", "low", "med", "high", "low", "med"
$ integer   <int> 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
$ double    <dbl> 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5.5, 6.5
$ logical   <lgl> TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, NA, TRUE
$ date      <IDate> 2022-04-04, 2022-04-03, 2022-04-02, 2022-04-01, 2022-03-31, …

demo_tsv$character # does not have the concept of levels

[1] "A" "B" "C" "D" "E" "F"

demo_tsv$dactor # has the concept of levels

NULL



#Using the spec() function allows you to change or treat things as they come in.
demo<- readr::read_csv("data/demo.csv")

Rows: 6 Columns: 6
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (2): character, factor
dbl  (2): integer, double
lgl  (1): logical
date (1): date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

corrected_cols <- cols(
  character = col_character(),
  factor = col_factor(levels = c("low", "med", "high")), # specify the order you want
  integer = col_integer(),
  double = col_double(),
  logical = col_logical(),
  date = col_date(format = "%Y-%m-%d")
)

demo <- readr::read_csv("data/demo.csv", col_types = corrected_cols)
spec(demo)

cols(
  character = col_character(),
  factor = col_factor(levels = c("low", "med", "high"), ordered = FALSE, include_na = FALSE),
  integer = col_integer(),
  double = col_double(),
  logical = col_logical(),
  date = col_date(format = "%Y-%m-%d")
)

glimpse(demo)

Rows: 6
Columns: 6
$ character <chr> "A", "B", "C", "D", "E", "F"
$ factor    <fct> high, low, med, high, low, med
$ integer   <int> 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
$ double    <dbl> 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5.5, 6.5
$ logical   <lgl> TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, NA, TRUE
$ date      <date> 2022-04-04, 2022-04-03, 2022-04-02, 2022-04-01, 2022-03-31, …


###Google Sheet Load Google SHeet

gs4_deauth() # skip authorisation for public data

demo_gs4  <- googlesheets4::read_sheet(
  ss = "16dkq0YL0J7fyAwT1pdgj1bNNrheckAU_2-DKuuM6aGI"
)

✔ Reading from "demo".


✔ Range 'Sheet1'.




Creating Data

avatar <- tibble( 
  name = c("Katara", "Toph", "Sokka"), # char string 
  bends = c("water", "earth", NA),
  friendly = TRUE,
  numbers = c(1,2,3),
  more_numbers = 1:3,
  even_more= seq(1,2,3)
)

# print it
avatar

# A tibble: 3 × 6
  name   bends friendly numbers more_numbers even_more
  <chr>  <chr> <lgl>      <dbl>        <int>     <dbl>
1 Katara water TRUE           1            1         1
2 Toph   earth TRUE           2            2         1
3 Sokka  <NA>  TRUE           3            3         1


###Export Data

#export(avatar, "data/avatar.csv")

###Writing Data

title: Week 4 Data Vis
text:
Data types: Show that you understand what is available to you in R. Note also, this goal overlaps with part of the midterm project. See the appendix on Data Types in the textbook for help. Write notes and R code chunks to demonstrate your knowledge
Tidy Data: Show that you understand what this means. Give an example of data this is in tidy format, and data that is not.
ggplot2: We will continue learning about this across the semester. Show at a minimum that you can make a graph and add it to your blog. Try examples from the textbook. Show that you understand the layer concept. Identify aspects that are confusing to you so we can discuss them in class.


#run in console
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ──
✔ ggplot2 3.4.0     ✔ purrr   1.0.1
✔ tibble  3.1.8     ✔ dplyr   1.1.0
✔ tidyr   1.3.0     ✔ stringr 1.5.0
✔ readr   2.1.3     ✔ forcats 1.0.0
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

starwars_copy <- starwars

# class function gives you the data type
# Check out some of the data types
head(starwars_copy) 

# A tibble: 6 × 14
  name         height  mass hair_…¹ skin_…² eye_c…³ birth…⁴ sex   gender homew…⁵
  <chr>         <int> <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>     <dbl> <chr> <chr>  <chr>  
1 Luke Skywal…    172    77 blond   fair    blue       19   male  mascu… Tatooi…
2 C-3PO           167    75 <NA>    gold    yellow    112   none  mascu… Tatooi…
3 R2-D2            96    32 <NA>    white,… red        33   none  mascu… Naboo  
4 Darth Vader     202   136 none    white   yellow     41.9 male  mascu… Tatooi…
5 Leia Organa     150    49 brown   light   brown      19   fema… femin… Aldera…
6 Owen Lars       178   120 brown,… light   blue       52   male  mascu… Tatooi…
# … with 4 more variables: species <chr>, films <list>, vehicles <list>,
#   starships <list>, and abbreviated variable names ¹​hair_color, ²​skin_color,
#   ³​eye_color, ⁴​birth_year, ⁵​homeworld

class(starwars_copy$name)

[1] "character"

class(starwars_copy$height)

[1] "integer"

#plot some of the variables
ggplot(data = starwars_copy,
  mapping = aes (x= height, y = mass) )+ 
  geom_point()

Warning: Removed 28 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).






typeof(10.02454353424)

[1] "double"

typeof(10L)

[1] "integer"

typeof(10)

[1] "double"



#Nominal
typeof("1")

[1] "character"


Date: 02/22/23

# Assign 1 to object named a
a <- 1
2 -> b
#Will change the interger into a character
as.character(1)

[1] "1"

title: Week 4 Data Vis
text:
Data.frame

my_df <- data.frame(a=1:5,
                    b = c ("one", "two", "three", "four", "five"),
                    random = runif(5,0,1))
#print to view
my_df

  a     b    random
1 1   one 0.6223165
2 2   two 0.4008780
3 3 three 0.2232768
4 4  four 0.1691337
5 5  five 0.6274740



#Access parts of the table
my_df[1,] # row 1, all columns

  a   b    random
1 1 one 0.6223165

my_df[,1] # column 1, all rows

[1] 1 2 3 4 5

my_df[1:2,3] # row 1 and 2 and column 3

[1] 0.6223165 0.4008780


#ggplot

survey_data <- read_csv("https://psyteachr.github.io/ads-v2/data/survey_data.csv")

Rows: 707 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (3): caller_id, employee_id, issue_category
dbl  (3): wait_time, call_time, satisfaction
dttm (1): call_start

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

head(survey_data)

# A tibble: 6 × 7
  caller_id employee_id call_start          wait_time call_time issue_…¹ satis…²
  <chr>     <chr>       <dttm>                  <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>      <dbl>
1 C001      E01         2020-09-22 10:47:54       169        34 tech           3
2 C002      E01         2020-09-07 22:10:25       206        52 tech           2
3 C003      E01         2020-07-06 12:08:59       207        41 tech           2
4 C004      E01         2020-02-20 13:12:03       132        16 tech           4
5 C005      E01         2020-11-08 17:42:10       178        20 returns        3
6 C006      E01         2020-06-01 19:06:12       230        46 returns        2
# … with abbreviated variable names ¹​issue_category, ²​satisfaction

library(tidyverse)


ggplot()



#| fig-width 250
#ggplot(data=survey_data,
       #mapping = aes(x= wait_time, y=satisfaction))
#same as above
ggplot(survey_data,aes(x= wait_time, y=satisfaction,)) + geom_point(color="black", size = 5)+ geom_point(color="blue",size= 3) + geom_smooth(method = "lm") + geom_smooth()

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'




ggplot(survey_data,aes(x= wait_time, y=satisfaction, color= satisfaction)) +geom_point()

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Tip Sheet Week 2
text:
Date: 02/06/23
How to commit and push changes to GitHub:

Make changes to file
Render the website in R Studio
Commit the changes in GitHub desktop with a commit message
Push to github.com

(You can use R Studio as well)
Can enter a package without enabling it by using ::
beepr::beep()
Inputs to functions
beep (sound = 8, expr = NULL)
Date: 02/08/23
Use help to load the help file for functions or ?function_name Ex. ?mean to find mean function
??function_name look for functions inside of packages you have not loaded Ex. ??Mean
help (“mean”, package=“base”)
c() funtion in R my
mean(as.numeric(c(“1”,“2”,“3”))
